awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry. Professor Philippe Buhlmann of the University of Minnesota - Twin Cities is developing redox buffer polymers and redox buffer nanoporous carbons to demonstrate their application for sensors. This approach extends the sensor lifetime and requires no calibration. Chemical sensors are used to measure the concentration of chemical species in water, food, industrial liquids, and biological samples in a similar way as a thermometer is used to measure temperature. In particular, electrochemical sensors with high selectivities are used for billions of measurements of ion concentrations annually. Unfortunately, conventional ion sensors must be recalibrated frequently, which requires a constant supply of reagents and either automation or trained personnel. This complicates point-of-care applications and raises cost. This work eliminates the need for recalibration. Broader impacts are also evidenced through the inclusion of high school students in the research activities  and outreach activities that introduce sensors in hands-on-activies in community libraries. 

Polymers and nanoporous carbon materials with a redox buffer capacity at a well-defined electrochemical potential offer a unique way to prepare calibration-free sensors. The materials developed in this project exhibit features distinguishing them from previously reported polymers and carbons with redox-active groups: they exhibit batch-independent electrochemical potentials with a high reproducibility and good long-term chemical stabilities. These properties result from two design principles: (i) the redox buffer polymers and nanoporous carbons incorporate both the oxidized and reduced form of a distinct redox couple in equal quantitities, defining the potential as given by the Nernst equation. (ii) the redox-active groups are specifically selected to be stable under ambient conditions both in the oxidized and reduced form. The response mechanism of potentiometric sensors using these new materials is thoroughly investigated, which includes the quantification of electron and ion conductivities in the redox buffer polymers as well as the interfacial electron and ion transfer kinetics.

por.por_cntn:
Potentiometric ion sensors are used for billions of measurements in hospitals across the world, most often using blood and urine samples. They are also widely used to monitor industrial processes and to measure changes in the environment. Unfortunately, conventional ion sensors must be recalibrated frequently, requiring a constant supply of calibration solutions and either automation or trained personnel. This complicates point-of-care applications, makes use for laypersons difficult, and raises cost. This project has developed solid-contact ion-selective electrodes with integrated redox buffers and demonstrated their application for the fabrication of potentiometric solid-state sensors. The use of redox buffers as transducer layer between polymeric ionophore-doped sensing membranes and the underlying electron conductors is crucial to meet key challenges in the development of electroanalytical sensors, i.e., (i) elimination of the need for calibration and (ii) considerable enhancement of the lifetime of remotely deployed and implantable devices.

   Redox buffers with a well-defined electrochemical potential offer an exciting way to prepare calibration-free sensors. Numerous reports on redox polymers were made, but until very recently the literature has contained hardly any reference to redox buffers and their use in electroanalytical chemistry. In our work, we have shown that ion-selective electrodes (ISEs) comprising redox buffers exhibit batch-independent electrochemical potentials reproducible to 1 mV. We have shown this both with hydrophilic and hydrophobic redox buffers. These properties result from two design principles: (i) ISEs comprising a redox buffer incorporate both the oxidized and reduced form of a distinct redox couple in an equal ratio, defining the potential as given by E = Eo - R T n-1 F-1 ln (ared/aox). (ii) The redox-active groups are specifically selected to be stable under ambient conditions both in the oxidized and reduced form.

   The lifetime of our ISEs also benefit from the covalent attachment of the sensing membranes to the underlying ISE platform substrate, which we have demonstrated for the first time using an inert plastic format. This platform substrate may be flexible, making the sensors suitable as wearable and implantable devices. We have done so using a woven textile fabric prepared from synthetic monomers, demonstrating the fabrication of potentiometric sensors into which the sensor is fully integrated. This same platform is also suitable for affordable point-of-care applications and. because of the high purity of the textile, we have been able to demonstrate lower limits of detection for chloride than for comparable paper-based devices.

   As these type of sensors are becoming more and more long term stable, reference electrodes that used to be fully satisfactory a decade ago are no longer meeting the needs of real life applications. To that end, we have also developed reference electrode that interface samples through a pressurized capillary. The use of a narrow-bore capillary minimizes the contamination of samples with reference/bridge electrolyte. At the same time, the low volume flow of the reference/bridge electrolyte into the sample, as enabled by the very small cross-sectional area of the capillary, makes it possible to use high linear flow rates of the bridge electrolyte, effectively preventing contamination of the reference half cell with components of samples. Using this approach, we have been able to demonstrate signal drifts as low as a few microvolt per hour, meeting the needs for use in combination with modern solid contact potentiometric sensors.
